Indications and doses

Susceptible infections in patients with penicillin hypersensitivity (e.g. respiratory-tract infections (including Legionella infection), skin and oral infections, and campylobacter enteritis),

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    250–500 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 500–1000 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For adults
    6.25 mg/kg every 6 hours, for mild infections when oral treatment not possible. increased to 12.5 mg/kg every 6 hours, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    125 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 250 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For children 2–7 years
    250 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 500 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For children 8–17 years
    250–500 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 500–1000 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For children
    12.5 mg/kg every 6 hours (max. per dose 1 g).

Lyme disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg 4 times a day for 14–21 days.

Early syphilis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg 4 times a day for 14 days.

Uncomplicated genital chlamydia, Non-gonococcal urethritis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily for 14 days.

Chronic prostatitis,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    250–500 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 4 g daily in divided doses, dose increase may be used severe infections.
  • For adults
    6.25 mg/kg every 6 hours, for mild infections when oral treatment is not possible, increased to 12.5 mg/kg every 6 hours, dose increase may be used in severe infections.

Prevention and treatment of pertussis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    (consult local protocol).
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    125 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 250 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For children 2–7 years
    250 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 500 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.
  • For children 8–17 years
    250–500 mg 4 times a day, total daily dose may alternatively be given in two divided doses, increased to 500–1000 mg 4 times a day, dose increase may be used in severe infections.

Prevention of secondary case of diphtheria in non-immune patient,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg every 6 hours for 7 days, treat for further 10 days if nasopharyngeal swabs positive after first 7 days' treatment.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    125 mg every 6 hours for 7 days, treat for further 10 days if nasopharyngeal swabs positive after first 7 days' treatment.
  • For children 2–7 years
    250 mg every 6 hours for 7 days, treat for further 10 days if nasopharyngeal swabs positive after first 7 days' treatment.
  • For children 8–17 years
    500 mg every 6 hours for 7 days, treat for further 10 days if nasopharyngeal swabs positive after first 7 days' treatment.

Prevention of secondary case of invasive group A streptococcal infection in penicillin allergic patients,

By mouth

  • For adults
    250–500 mg every 6 hours for 10 days.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    125 mg every 6 hours for 10 days.
  • For children 2–7 years
    250 mg every 6 hours for 10 days.
  • For children 8–17 years
    250–500 mg every 6 hours for 10 days.

Prevention of pneumococcal infection in asplenia or in patients with sickle-cell disease, and who are penicillin allergic,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily, antibiotic prophylaxis is not fully reliable. It may be discontinued in those over 5 years of age with sickle-cell disease who have received pneumococcal immunisation and who do not have a history of severe pneumococcal infection.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    125 mg twice daily, antibiotic prophylaxis is not fully reliable.
  • For children 2–7 years
    125 mg twice daily, antibiotic prophylaxis is not fully reliable. It may be discontinued in those over 5 years of age with sickle-cell disease who have received pneumococcal immunisation and who do not have a history of severe pneumococcal infection.
  • For children 8–17 years
    500 mg twice daily, antibiotic prophylaxis is not fully reliable. It may be discontinued in those over 5 years of age with sickle-cell disease who have received pneumococcal immunisation and who do not have a history of severe pneumococcal infection.

Prevention of recurrence of rheumatic fever,

By mouth

  • For children 1 month–1 year
    125 mg twice daily.
  • For children 2–17 years
    250 mg twice daily.

Rosacea,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily courses usually last 6–12 weeks and are repeated intermittently.

Acne,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With systemic use

Not known to be harmful.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

With systemic use

May cause idiosyncratic hepatotoxicity.

Advice regarding renal impairment

With systemic use in adults

Max. 1.5 g daily in severe renal impairment (ototoxicity).

With systemic use in children

Reduce dose in severe renal impairment (ototoxicity).

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

Dilute reconstituted solution further in glucose 5% (neutralised with Sodium bicarbonate) or sodium chloride 0.9% to a concentration of 1–5 mg/mL; give over 20–60 minutes.

Concentration of up to 10 mg/mL may be used in fluid-restriction if administered via a central venous catheter.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (as lactobionate), give intermittently in Glucose 5% (neutralised with sodium bicarbonate) or Sodium chloride 0.9%; dissolve initially in water for injections (1 g in 20 mL) then dilute to a concentration of 1–5 mg/mL; give over 20–60 minutes.

Advice for patients and carers

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Erythromycin for bacterial infections

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/erythromycin-for-bacterial-infections

Cautions regarding administration

  • With systemic use: avoid in Acute porphyrias
  • With systemic use: neonate under 2 weeks (risk of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) in neonates

Unlicensed use

With intravenous use or oral use in children

Not licensed for use in gastro-intestinal stasis.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

With oral use

Flavours of oral liquid formulations may include banana.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

Erythromycin tablets e/c may be prescribed.

Erythromycin ethyl succinate oral suspension may be prescribed.

Erythromycin stearate tablets may be prescribed.

Erythromycin ethyl succinate tablets may be prescribed.
